newsitem.title: FRANCE: French Socialist sentenced in party financing case.
newsitem.headline: French Socialist sentenced in party financing case.

text.p: A French court gave a former leader of the ruling Socialist Party, Henri Emmanuelli, an 18-month suspended sentence on Thursday for illicit party fundraising activities.
The court announced the sentence hours after the cabinet of Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin cabinet took office following the left's victory in last Sunday's parliamentary election.
The verdict, due a week ago, had been postponed to avoid interfering with the campaign. Emmanuelli was re-elected to parliament on Sunday.
A former cabinet minister who served as Socialist party treasurer in the 1980s and leader in 1994-95, Emmanuelli was charged with handling stolen goods and influence-peddling.

He had already been convicted on similar charges in a 1995 trial in Brittany when he was given a one-year suspended jail term and a 30,000 franc ($5,150) fine for receiving illicit campaign funds from a front company run by party insiders.
Emmanuelli took political reponsibility for schemes to funnel money to the party in the late 1980s via the Urba consultancy firm, which took rake-offs on public works contracts.
But he said he had not profited personally and denied breaking the law.
Lawyers argued that there had been a legal vacuum at the time on political financing.
All mainstream French parties ran covert funding schemes before a 1990 law put party finances on a legal footing.
Magistrates are investigating similar cases involving the centre-right RPR and UDF parties and the Communist party. ($ = 5.825 French Francs)
